dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at the funeral of Dorothy Kowalski. In attendance are mostly old folks, their offspring and several bored teenagers. WALT KOWALSKI stands towards the front of the church. He speaks to an older MAN in a bulky, out-of-date suit.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: I'm real sorry about Dorothy, Walt. She was a real peach.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Al. Walt Kowalski looks young for his age. He has slate blue eyes, physically fit and has had the same buzz cut hairstyle since getting out of the military in 1953. Walt is also a perfectionist. Nothing escapes his hawklike eyes, eyes that pierce and judge. Walt looks around at how the young people have dressed at his wife's funeral. His eyes narrow at his GRANDDAUGHTER's belly button ring.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Walt's two sons, MITCH and STEVE, watch their father from across the pews.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Look at the Old Man glaring at Ashley. He can't even tone it down at Mom's funeral?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What do you expect? Dad's still living in the В‘50s. He expects his granddaughter to dress a little more modestly.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well your kid's wearing a Timberwolves jersey. I'm sure Dad appreciates that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My point is that there's nothing anyone can do that won't disappoint the Old Man. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 3
dialogues.text: It's inevitable. That's why we stopped doing Thanksgivings; the deal with the boat motor, the broken bird bath, it's always something.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What are we going to do with him? Don't you think he'll get in trouble by himself over in the old neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why don't you have him move in with you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir sings the Beatitudes. Walt looks around disgustedly at the people gathered as one woman looks through her day planner, an old guy dozes and his Granddaughter Ashley applies nail polish. FATHER JANOVICH, the very young parish priest, steps up to the altar and delivers the eulogy for Walt's wife. Walt sits ramrod straight and listens to the thin, weak, unconvincing words of Father Janovich.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Death... is often a bittersweet occasion to us Catholics. Bitter in the pain it causes the deceased ... and their families. Sweet to those who know the salvation that awaits them. And some may ask, what is death. Is it the end? Or is it the beginning? And what is life? What is this thing we call life?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus. Walt coughs. He takes a handkerchief and wipes his lips. He looks down and notices a speck of BLOOD on the white cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is crammed with people following the service. Walt doesn't know what to do with himself. He has to keep busy. Steve steps over to his father.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A lot of people showed up after the service.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I s'pose they knew there'd be plenty of ham. I think I'll go downstairs and get some more chairs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'll do it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Naw, we need them now, not next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandsons JOSH, DANIEL and DAVID look through boxes in the cellar. A box of old Korea War photos are pawed through. Josh holds up a black-and-white PHOTO -- a young WALT looks utterly exhausted, behind him six bodies are sprawled dead on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, it's Grandpa Walt. Josh turns the photo over and reads it...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: В‘Third Platoon, E company, March second, 1952, Korea.'

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Where's Korea?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hell if I know? David holds up a MEDAL. 3. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Cool, I found a medal. They hear someone coming downstairs. By the time Walt descends the staircase, the boys sit on the couch, pretending to be doing nothing. Walt gives them a hard look as he grabs some chairs.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: 5 5 People eat and chat. Ashley marches over to her parents, KAREN and Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY, (GRANDDAUGHTER)
dialogues.text: How long do we have to stay, this ghetto is a dead zone for my cell and I'm bored. Walt stands behind them with an armful of folding chairs, he overheard his Granddaughter. Mitch and Karen are embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ashley, honey. Why don't you help Grandpa Walt with the chairs?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes you.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Grandpa Walt, can I help you with the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it, you just painted your nails. Walt opens the folding chairs and looks out the window. It's snowing. Walt puts on his coat, he almost looks relieved to get out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'd better salt the sidewalk before someone falls and breaks a hip. Walt taps the floor with his boot and DAISY, his very, very, very old DOG follows him outside. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 6 Walt carefully shovels his sidewalk. He deliberately stops at the boundary of his property. The reason for this is that Walt's neighbors are now mostly Asians who moved into the house that once belonged to Polish families. Next door to Walt's house some sort of party is going on. Walt can see through the window that the living room is jammed with at least forty people, all Asians, all Hmong. And this is a problem for Walt, because Walt is a full- blown, unrepentant racist. Walt lights a cigarette and speaks to his dog, Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, how many swamp rats can they cram into a living room? Walt spits in the snow and walks back to the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 7 Walt steps inside and catches Ashley sneaking a cigarette. She has pulled back the canvas tarp that covers his pride and joy, his beloved 1972 GRAN TORINO. The Gran Torino is in mint condition. It has been babied since the day it rolled off the line. Ashley tosses her cigarette when she sees Grandpa Walt.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Wow, Grandpa, when'd you get the vintage car? Walt looks at her for a second, then steps on her still burning cigarette before answering.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: I never knew you had a cool old car.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It's only been in here since before you were born. 5. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: So, what are you like going to do with it like, when... you die? Walt lights up a smoke --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus, Joseph and Mary. Walt pulls the cover back over the Gran Torino.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Then what about that super cool retro couch in the den, I'm going to State next year and I don't have, like, any furniture? Walt walks out without commenting.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN WALT'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: 8 8 The doorbell rings and Walt opens the door. Standing there is TAO, a sixteen-year-old HMONG boy. Walt scowls. TAO is slight, he has long hair, long lashes, but is very good-looking -- like an Asian Johnny Depp.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (very quietly) I'm Tao, I live next door.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?! Speak up, boy, get the shit out of your mouth. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Do you have jumper cables? My uncle's car is old and...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. And have some goddamned respect, zipper head, we're mourning over here. Walt slams the door in Tao's face. Walt turns and is suddenly cornered by Father Janovich. Walt hates situations like this. 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 7 7 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: How you holding up, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It's Mr. Kowalski, not Walt.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Right, Mr. Kowalski. Your wife and I became quite close these last few months. She asked that I watch over you when she passed on. I told her I watch out for my entire flock, but she made me promise I'd keep an extra sharp eye on you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I appreciate your kindness to my wife and now that you've spoken your piece, why don't you move on to the next sheep? Walt starts to step away, but Father Janovich blocks him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Dorothy mentioned specifically that it was her wish for you to go to confession. She said she couldn't remember the last time you went.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: It is. Walt drains his lowball glass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, I confess I never much liked church and only went because of the wife. And I confess I have no desire to confess to a boy who is fresh out of the seminary. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 9 People are leaving Walt's house. A mass of shuffling, stiff-jointed old Pollacks. Right next door -- walking the opposite direction are more Hmong going up the sidewalk. They laugh and chatter and carry big dishes of food and fruit. They are a happy bunch compared to the dour crowd exiting Walt's home. The Hmong are going to a birth ceremony. A three-day-old baby is named and three souls are located for the newborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt leans over a car that contains two shivering old ladies from the funeral. He hooks up the jumper cables to their dead battery. Mitch, Karen, Ashley and Josh pull up next to Walt in a brand new Toyota Land Cruiser. Mitch opens the window.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I'd really like to help, Dad, but we have to get the kids home, they're getting restless. Walt just looks at the TOYOTA EMBLEM on the Land Cruiser and then gives Mitch a disgusted glance.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Fine. Go.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I'll call in a few, see how you're doing. Walt nods and lights a cigarette as they drive off.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Kill you to buy American.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did you see him look at the truck? It's always Rice-Burner this or Jap-Buggy that. Even at Mom's funeral, he can't let it go. 8. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: At least he didn't say anything this time.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He didn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, what do you expect? The man worked at a Ford plant for twenty- eight years.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: And I suppose that's my goddamned fault?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON WALT
dialogues.text: 11 11 Walt gets his guests' engine running. As they drive off, Walt hears faint SINGING. Walt looks into his neighbor's backyard and can't believe his eyes. The Hmong all sing and chant as three CHICKENS have their heads sliced off, right there in the yard. The chickens are held up and everyone chants louder. It's a sacrifice. Walt spits in the snow and says to Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Barbarians. Goddamned barbarians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 12 The house is a buzz of activity. The older Hmong speak their native language, the younger generation speaks both English and Hmong. (NOTE: Hmong is subtitled when necessary.) Tao's Grandmother (PHONG) complains to a MAN.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no man in this house, that's why my daughter should remarry. Being a second wife is better than having a woman be the head of the household. It's not our way. 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 10 10 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Tao?

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the man in the house.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tao's not a man. (GESTURES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him in the kitchen, washing dishes like a woman. Even his sister gives him orders and he obeys. The CAMERA PANS TO the kitchen where TAO washes a pile of dishes. An older relative drops dishes in the sink, without acknowledging Tao's presence. It's clearly an insult. In the LIVING ROOM the Hmong В“Soul CallingВ” ceremony starts its next phase. An elder, the family SHAMAN, is present and begins the ritual. As the entire Hmong family gathers to watch. Tao slips on his coat and goes out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 13 Tao wobbles as he pedals his bike through the snow. Tao passes Walt's garage and is startled as Walt appears from a shadow, JUMPER CABLES in his hands. They make eye contact as Tao passes. Walt spits in the snow and looks down at Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I thought these zips were supposed to be such hard workers. Christ, I had my own car when I was his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 14 Tao exits the store, gets on his bike and rides off. 10.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 12 12 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 12
dialogues.text: A few blocks away, Tao rides past a snowbank when -- WHAM! A HOCKEY STICK is thrown through the spokes of his front wheel. Tao flies over the handlebars into the snow. A chorus of laughter is heard. Three LATINOS stand around the stunned, prone Tao.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD LATINO
dialogues.text: Whatta you gonna do, gook? You gonna В‘Kung Fu' us? Tao just lies there as Latino #2 picks up his bike.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: Surprised it ain't a girl's bike. The Latinos laugh. Tao remains on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD LATINO
dialogues.text: You gonna get up or what? Tao doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD LATINO
dialogues.text: Tell you what, I'll let you take the first swing. You drop me and you can have your bike back. Tao smiles, he can't help it.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD LATINO
dialogues.text: What the fuck you smiling at, gook? Something funny? He grabs Tao by the jacket and pulls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD LATINO
dialogues.text: You better get the fuck outta here, bitch. He pushes Tao backwards. Tao falls back into the snow. This time Tao crab-walks back away from the Latinos. The Latinos stroll away with Tao's bike.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Walt is going about the chores of spring cleaning. 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 14 14 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 13
dialogues.text: Walt looks around with disdain at his neighbors' houses. Walt's property is perfectly kept, whereas his neighbors' houses are rundown. Walt's eyes linger on every defect, gutter hangs, ripped screen doors, peeling paint. One neighbor has installed a chicken coop. Walt looks down at Daisy --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Damn chinks let their yards go to hell. Polarski would turn over in his grave if he could see what they did to his lawn. Tao walks past. Walt watches him pass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't know why these goddamned slopes had to move to my block. This used to be a nice neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 16 Tao nods to an older woman rocking in a broken rocking chair. PHONG nods back to Tao, then turns her evil eye back on Walt, whom she's been seething at all morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't that stupid, hairy white man move? He must be too dumb to realize he's not welcome here. All the Mee-Khah left in the neighborhood should just move away. Look at him strut like a rooster. She sees Walt glance at her and spit. Phong glares back and spits beetle juice, which has turned her teeth black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 17 Daisy snoozes next to the front door. The doorbell rings; Daisy doesn't even move. Walt walks to the front door holding a roll of duct tape. The doorbell rings again. Walt looks down at Daisy -- 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 15 15 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, dog, have you gone totally deaf? Walt opens the door. Standing on his front step is Father Janovich.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Hi there, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Listen, son, you're not my barber, you're not a friend, so why in the hell do you think you can call me Walt?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Sorry... Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So, what are you peddling now?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. Thought I'd drop by and see how you were doing. Haven't seen you in church in awhile.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay. You've done your good deed, now why don't you run along.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'd really like to talk, Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't think so, kid. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Why? Do you have a problem with me, Mr. Kowalski?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: No, I do.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: The problem is I think you're an overeducated, 27-year-old virgin who holds the hands of superstitious old women and promises them eternity. 13.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 17 17 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 15
dialogues.text: Walt shuts the front door in Father Janovich's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 18 Tao walks down the street, his head in a book. He finally realizes there's a blue Chevy following slowly behind him. The blue Chevy is now parallel with Tao and keeps pace with his step. Tao looks over to the occupants of the Chevy. It's two LATINOS. Tao quickens his pace, but the Chevy easily keeps up with Tao.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Is you a boy or a girl, I can't tell?

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: What you reading, gook, Jackass And The Rice Stalk? Tao laughs, but keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO DRIVER
dialogues.text: That's right, you keep walking. Fucking slopes everywhere you look, man. Why gooks come up in here and fuck up our neighborhood? Down the street -- is a suped-up HONDA CIVIC with a big SPOILER on the back. Inside are five Hmong gangbangers. The Hmong gangbangers notice Tao being followed by the Latinos. SPIDER, the driver, squints and then points at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Dude, that's my little cousin, Tao.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You sure about that, Spider?

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: I'm sure. Do we do something... or what? Smokie is the gang leader. He looks at Tao for a second.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Your cousin tight with anyone? 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 17 17 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: No, he flies solo, Smokie.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go help out our little cousin. Smokie nods to Spider, they roar up and stop right across from Tao and the Latinos' car.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You better not be giving my bro here a hard time or you're gonna wish you never been born.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Oh goody, more Rice Niggers. The Latino Driver smiles and flashes a PISTOL. A Hmong kid in the back seat opens the door and displays a sub-machine gun. The Latinos are way out-gunned.

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: Fucking Viet Cong swamp rats. Go back to your fucking rice paddy. The Latinos screech their tires and are gone. The Hmongs in the car smile and congratulate themselves. Tao simply keeps walking down the street!

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Where the fuck does he think he's going? Turn us around and go after that cousin of yours. They swing a U-turn and pull up to Tao, keeping pace with him as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Hey, cuz, slow down, where you going? You should really think about hanging with us, man. If we all stick together, shit like that won't happen, with those Spicks. Tao nods as he walks, but doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: You can't be such a little girl. You join up with us, we'll keep you out of trouble, cuz. 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 18 18 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 17
dialogues.text: Tao looks at the sub-machine gun cradled by the Hmong gangbanger in the back seat. Smokie takes this all in. He looks down the street and sees that in a half block, Tao will have to pass a group of Latino gangbanger types.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You think about it and we'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 19 Tao digs in the garden. Tao's younger sister SUE sits and reads JANE magazine on the porch. The tricked-out Honda with Blue Neon lights pulls up. Spider, Smokie and two other Hmong gangbangers get out.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Hey, cuz. Hey, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Came to talk to my cousin Tao. Smokie looks over to Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Spider, who's the other cousin? SUE laughs at the name В“Spider.В” Sue is seventeen, has long straight hair with red highlights.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: В‘Spider'? Is that what he just called you, Fong?

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: This is my little cousin, Sue. Smokie takes off his sunglasses and smiles at Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Sue... how old are you, girl?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Mentally, I'm way too old for you. I'm going inside. 16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 18 18 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: That's right, go inside while the men talk.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's exactly what I'm doing, Fong. Sue rolls her eyes and goes inside. Smokie stares at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: You think about what we talked about? A PAUSE. Smokie watches Tao carefully, offers him a cigarette. Tao shakes his head В“noВ” and looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: That's exactly the point, Tao. Spider told me how everyone thinks you're a pushover, how everybody walks all over you and shit. I mean, look at you, out here working in the garden like a woman. Tao nods silently, but still looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: It ain't no big thing. You just need a little guidance. Tao looks up at Smokie. Tao looks a little skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: It's true, man. Shit, I used to be kind of a quiet little punk like you, everybody fucking with me. But finally I said В‘no more.' You, you're lucky, Tao, we got your back. Me? I didn't have nobody. Had to mold my own tribe.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Smokie's right. We're family, right? You with us or what?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I swear, brother, we're the best friends you'll ever have. And anyone fucks with you, they're fucked. 17.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 19 19 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Come on, man. Tao clears his throat and speaks for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What do I have to do? Smokie points to Walt's open garage.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Spider mentioned that neighbor of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM IN -- There it sits with the tarp rolled back, Walt's gorgeous, shining GRAN TORINO.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Now that's a car.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit ya. 1972 Gran Torino fastback. Cobra jet engine. Mint. Next to the garage, Walt is bent over planting tomatoes. Walt notices the Hmong punks looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 20 Walt sits at the bar in the VFW (Veterans of Foreign Wars) drinking with the old buddies and cracking off- color jokes.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I got one. A Mexican, a Jew and a colored guy walk into a bar, the bartender looks up at them and says -- В‘get the fuck out.' The gang laughs, until they see Father Janovich step up to the bar. He smiles as he recognizes several faces.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: So, here's where my flock congregates when they're not in church. 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 19 19 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MEL
dialogues.text: Hiya, Father J.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Hi, Mel. Hey there, Darrel.

dialogues.speaker: DARREL
dialogues.text: Hello, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Hi, Walt. Walt says nothing. He just sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: DARREL
dialogues.text: What brings you in here, Father? The meat raffle?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: No. I came down to talk to Walt, if that's okay. Mel and Darrel look at Walt. It puts him on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I have to hand it to you, Padre. You are persistent.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I promised your wife. Walt looks over at Mel and Darrel and then back at Father Janovich.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ, let's grab a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 21 The waitress comes over.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll have a Pabst and a shot. What are you having, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'll have a Diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Bullshit, this is a bar, what do you want to drink? 19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 20 20 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Ummmm... I'll have a gin and tonic.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Attaboy. The waitress leaves.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I promised your wife I'd get you to go to confession.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, why'd you do that?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: She was very insistent. She made me.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You sure are fond of promising people stuff you can't deliver on.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Let's talk about something else.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Life and death.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What would you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'd like to think I know a lot. I'm a priest.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You stand at the altar and preach on and on about life and death without knowing anything other than what you learned in priest school. Everything you say sounds like it's out of the Rookie Preachers Handbook.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I don't know about that... 20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 21 21 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 22
dialogues.text: Walt waves his hand and cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: В‘Death is bittersweet? Bitter in the pain, sweet in the salvation.' That's what you know of life and death? Good God, it's pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What do you know, Mr. Kowalski?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Plenty. I lived with death for three years in Korea. We shot people, we stabbed them with bayonets, we hacked seventeen-year- old kids to death with shovels, for Christ's sake. I did things that won't leave me till the day I die, horrible things, things I have to live with.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: And what about life? Walt has to think for a second. He struggles with his answer.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well... I survived the war... got married... and raised a family.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Sounds like you know more about death than you do living. Walt downs a shot.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Maybe so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 22 Walt hears a sound and wakes up. He's very groggy, he had plenty to drink at the VFW.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Daisy? The dog sleeps in her bed in the corner. Walt looks at the clock; it's 3:48 am. Walt looks out his bedroom window. He sees the faint beam of a flashlight in his garage. 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 21 21 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Walt pulls on his robe, opens the closet and pulls out the big, 30-06 M1 Garand Rifle he took home from Korea. Walt slides a magazine into the top of the M1 and chambers a round with a loud SNAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 23 The light flips on and before he can blink, Tao is face to face with the barrel of Walt's M1 RIFLE. Walt is silent, he has one eye closed so he can better aim at Tao's forehead -- which is nine inches away. Tao drops the tool he was holding, it bounces with a loud metallic clang. Tao backs away, his eyes wide with terror. As Tao backs up, Walt advances, step for step. Tao trips over a garden hose, which causes Walt to trip. They both start to fall. The lightbulb is bumped with the rifle barrel and swings back and forth. As Walt hits the garage floor, he accidentally FIRES THE RIFLE. The bullet goes through a big, metal Hamm's Beer sign on the wall. Tao scrambles to his feet and jumps like a deer over Walt. Tao runs out of the garage and into the night. Walt lies on the floor for a second, stunned. Sweat runs down his forehead. He coughs up blood. The lightbulb still swings, casting odd shadows in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 24 Tao scrambles down the alley. Parked off to the side is Spider's Honda. Spider opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Get in, get in! Tao runs right past him. Spider guns the motor and pulls in front of Tao. Smokie, Spider and another gangbanger get out. 22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 22 22 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Get in, Tao.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No way. No fucking way. Leave me alone! Smokie, Spider and the other gangbanger grab Tao.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: I vouched for you, Tao, because you're family and you're with us now. Tao struggles.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: He shot at me! I'm out! I'm out!!! Tao squirms out of Smokie's grasp. Smokie yells at Tao as he runs away...

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Don't fool yourself, Tao. You don't join us and bail. Dumb motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Should we go after him?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Naw, he's got nowhere to go. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 25 Walt drills heavy-gauge screen mesh over the windows on the garage. The phone rings and Walt answers.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Morning, Dad, it's your number one son, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It's one in the afternoon. The CAMERA now INTERCUTS BETWEEN Walt and Mitch in the kitchen of his huge, modern suburban house. 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 24 24 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Right, good afternoon, then.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Me? Nothing. What would I want?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't know. Your wife already went through all of your mother's jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No. I was just wondering how you are, what's going on, anything new in the old neighborhood? Walt looks at the bullet hole in his Hamm's Beer sign.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Great. Smooth sailing then?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yup. There's a very painful pause in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Well good... Say, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Do you still know that guy from the plant who has Viking season tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 26 Walt has parked the Gran Torino at an angle across his driveway. Walt mutters as he rubs Turtle Wax on his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 27 Walt fishes out a soft pack of cigarettes and lights one. He exhales as he looks at his car. 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 25 25 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 26
dialogues.text: It's stunning. It absolutely sparkles. The chrome shines, the tires look new and the paint is waxed and polished. Walt looks up again and his eyes sweep the neighborhood in defiance. A couple of Hmong teenagers look at the car.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, ain't she pretty. Walt drops down heavily into an old lawn chair and pops open a can of Pabst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 28 Dusk is falling. Walt finally gets up, folds up his lawn chair and walks stiffly back into the garage. Walt flips on the outdoor light, highlighting the Gran Torino still sitting at an angle in the driveway. The whole scene looks like a mid-sixties car ad in Popular Mechanics. Walt goes in the back door and a moment later the kitchen light comes on. The Gran Torino remains in the driveway. It's a challenge, an invitation. Walt is daring the thief to come back. And Walt's ready this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 29 The tricked-out Honda drives up, but doesn't stop at Walt's. It pulls up in front of Tao's house. Tao and Sue exchange looks out on the front step. Smokie, Spider and two others get out, walking confidently up the sidewalk towards them. They grin, they're cocky.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Hey, cuz. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Be happy. We've got good news. 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 27 27 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh really? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: We're giving you another shot.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You blew it the first time. We've got another little inauguration planned for you. This time there'll be no mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Another big, tough gangbanger with В‘little-man' complex. Smokie leers at Sue. It makes her uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I got my eye on you too, little girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Tao. Let's go. Tao says nothing. He looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: He said, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Come on, man. Nobody's gonna get hurt. We'll take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don't go, Tao.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You mind your own business, girl. Two Hmong gangbangers grab Tao by the arms. The front door swings open and there stands a glaring Phong.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave my grandson alone! 26.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 29 29 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 28
dialogues.text: I know what you are. Go away and don't come back.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: That old woman's got bigger balls than you. You always let little girls and old ladies fight for you? Tao tries to squirm away. Smokie grabs him by the hair and opens his coat to reveal the PISTOL in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna say it again. Let's go. Now. Tao is shoved towards the car. Suddenly -- Sue jumps on the back of one of the gangbangers and knocks him to the ground. Tao breaks free.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Run, Tao, run! Sue is slapped to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: RUN
dialogues.text: Tao is tackled by Smokie and punched in the face. Tao's mother comes out the front door. Smokie and Spider pull Tao towards the car as the other gangbangers keep Mom, Grandma and Sue at bay. A middle-aged Hmong Man from across the street comes into the yard. All the gangbangers overreact and pull their pistols. The middle-aged Hmong Man gets in Spider's face and is cracked across the jaw with a pistol barrel. Tao back-pedals away from Spider and Smokie. It becomes a pushing, rolling, surging melee. This mess boils over and spills into Walt's front yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 30 The gangbangers, Tao, his mother, grandmother and Sue all struggle on Walt's painstakingly maintained lawn. A ceramic Lawn Gnome is knocked over and breaks. 27.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 29
dialogues.text: And before anyone can blink, WALT has the muzzle of his big 30-06 M1 Garand Rifle pointing at Smokie's face.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Get off my lawn.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Listen, old man, you don't want...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I said get off my lawn. Now. Walt's calm demeanor is unnerving to the gangbangers. The guns in their hands seem tiny compared to the big military rifle Walt holds.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Are you fucking crazy? Go back in your house, old man.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Get off my lawn.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I'm not fucking around, Gramps. Walt spits out the side of his mouth. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't think for a second I won't blow a big hole in your face and it won't bother me a bit, not any more than if I shot a deer. Now get off my goddamned lawn. Two of the Hmong gangbangers take a step back. Walt senses their fear. Only Smokie holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Believe me, kid, I'll blow your damn head off, go back to bed and sleep like a baby. I couldn't care less.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna warn you again! Walt laughs...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You're nothing to me. In Korea, we stacked fucks like you five feet high and used you as sandbags. 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 30 30 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 30
dialogues.text: Complete silence, there's no sound anywhere in the neighborhood. All eyes are on Walt. Walt CLICKS OFF the safety on the M1 Garand Rifle. Smokie and the gangbangers give Walt fierce looks, but melt back towards their car. As they get into the car -- Smokie has to say something.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You better watch yourself, old man. The Honda screeches its tires and goes off down the street. Walt looks at Tao, Sue, Mom and Grandma who stand in stunned silence in his front yard. A PAUSE. Finally, Sue speaks up...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Walt lowers his rifle and spits on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I said get off my lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 31 We hear a sound outside. Walt grabs his rifle, swings open the front door and leads with the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 32 Walt looks around and slowly lowers his rifle. His front porch is covered with FLOWERS and FRUIT and GIFTS of food. There must be a dozen different gifts piled there. Daisy comes out and stretches on the porch, before putting her nose in a food basket.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Bad dog. Bad deaf, dumb, blind dog. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 33 Walt carries three big bouquets of flowers to the trash. He dumps them on top of other gifts he received from the Hmongs. His garbage is overflowing. Coming down the alley is another Hmong couple, they smile carrying a basket filled with Asian vegetables. Walt holds up his hand like a traffic cop.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. No more. The Hmong couple nod, say something with a smile and turn around.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT DOOR
dialogues.text: Tao, his mother and Sue argue in the yard. They gesture towards Walt's house. The women buzz around Tao, all speaking in his ear at the same time. Phong yells at them from the porch, but they ignore her. Walt watches as the mother and Sue march Tao towards his house. Tao looks like a whipped dog.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why won't these people leave me alone? Walt walks out to meet them at his property line and puts up his hands, indicating they've come far enough. Sue holds up a plant.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We brought you some shallots to plant in your garden.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't want them.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: They're perennials, they come back every year.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. You keep them. Why do you people keep giving me all this garbage? Sue is a little taken aback. 30. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Because... because you saved Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. All I did was get a bunch of jabbering gooks off my lawn.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, you're a hero to the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Too bad, they think you are and that's why they're bringing you the gifts.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Just take your plant and leave me alone. Walt turns and starts to walk away. Tao's mother speaks rapidly in Hmong to Sue. They look at Tao and then to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: There's another thing.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: This is my mother, Vu, I'm Sue and this is my brother, Tao. We live next door.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Tao is here to apologize. Sue shoots a hard look at Tao, who shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: For what? 31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 33 33 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: For trying to steal your car. Walt's eyes go wide in recognition. He turns white with rage.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Get this straight, I see you on my property again, you're done. Walt turns on his heels and storms into his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 34 The doorbell rings. Walt opens it to find Father Janovich standing on his front step.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Walt. Walt's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I mean, Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I already told you I'm not going to confession.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just call the police?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I do work with some of the Hmong gangs and I heard there was some trouble in the neighborhood. Why didn't you call the police?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh, I prayed for them to show up, but guess what? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What were you thinking? Someone could have been killed. We're talking life and death here. 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 33 33 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not that it's any of your goddamned business, but when things happen quickly like that, you have to react. In Korea, we never В‘called the police' when a swarm of screaming gooks came pouring into our lines. We reacted.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: We're not in Korea, Mr. Kowalski. Walt says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about our discussion on life and death. About what you said. About how you carry around the horrible things you were forced to do. Horrible things that won't leave you. It seems that it would do you good to unload some of that burden. Things done during war are terrible, being ordered to kill, killing to save others, killing to save yourself. You're right, those are things I don't know anything about. But I do know about forgiveness. And I've seen a lot of men who have confessed their sins, admitted their guilt and left their burdens behind them. Stronger men than you. Men at war who were ordered to do appalling things and are now at peace. Walt nods. Father Janovich threw a bull's-eye. Almost.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. You came with your guns loaded, for once.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have balls, Father. And what you said, you're right. I'm sure stronger men than me have found their salvation. Hallelujah. But there's one thing you're way wrong about. 33.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 34 34 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What's that, Mr. Kowalski?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: The thing that haunts a guy is the stuff he wasn't ordered to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 35 The old, balding BARBER finishes cutting Walt's hair.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: There, you look like a human being again. You shouldn't wait so long between haircuts, you cheap bastard.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm just amazed that you're still alive. I keep hoping you'll die and they'll get someone good in here, but you just hang in there, you dumb, Italian-Wop-Dago, you.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: That'll be ten dollars, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Ten dollars? Jesus Christ, Martin, you keep raising the price. You sure you're not part Jew? Martin the Barber laughs at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: It's been ten bucks for the last five years and you know it, you thick-skulled, old Pollack son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Here's ten, keep the change.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: See you in three weeks, you prick.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: If you live that long, dipshit. Walt and Martin shake hands and Walt walks out. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 36 Walt gets in his old Ford pickup and drives off. This is a very bad, rundown neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 37 Sue walks with her ridiculous Wigger (urban white kid) boyfriend, TREY. Trey wears big baggy pants, a sports jersey and an Oakland Raiders visor upside-down and backwards. They walk past three BLACK GUYS leaning against a building. The TALL BLACK GUY spots Sue and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, girl, you come over here and talk to me. Come on, baby, don't be shy. Trey and Sue move as far over on the sidewalk as they can to avoid the black guys. They try to ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetie, don't be like that. You talk to me, don't be all stuck up and shit.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: Walt waits at a stoplight. He watches Sue and Trey and the three black guys who block their path. One black guy flips Trey's VISOR onto the ground. The Tall Guy makes В“kissy facesВ” at Sue as he touches his crotch. Walt sits there for a second; he shouldn't help, but Walt solves every situation by being aggressive. Walt drives off, then makes a U-turn. The Tall Black Guy now focuses on Trey.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What are you В‘sposed to be? Trey puts up his hand to В“hi-five.В” The Tall Black Guy just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Yo, it's cool, dog. 35. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing in my neighborhood, boy?

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Nothing. We're going to Red Roost to get some CDs. That place is trippin', bro.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What you call me, you fucking with me, bitch? You think you're funny?

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Nothing. No.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, boy. What you all come up in here for? You here to bring me this present?

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: This Oriental yummy for me? Don't worry, I'll take good care of her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Great, another asshole with a fetish for Asian girls. God, it gets so old.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What's your name, girl?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My name? It's В‘take your crude, overly obvious come-on to every woman who walks past and cram it.' That's my name.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: You should keep your bitch on a leash, put a choke chain on this whore and yank.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course, right to the stereotype thesaurus. Call me В‘whore' and В‘bitch' in the same sentence. 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 37 37 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 38
dialogues.text: The Tall Black Guy grabs Sue by the arm. Trey moves slightly towards Sue and is pushed down into a pile of garbage.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: You think you're pretty funny, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What, are you gonna hit me now? That'd pretty much complete the picture. The Tall Black Guy pushes Sue hard against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: You don't know when to quit. The old, black pickup pulls up and stops next to them. Sue, Trey and the black guys look over. Walt sits behind the wheel, he looks right through the Tall Black Guy.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What the fuck you looking at, old man?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You... and your buddies. What's the matter with you? Don't any of you work? I see you lazy show- offs in the middle of the day, slowly walking across the street or harassing women. Nobody owes you bastards anything so go out and get a job instead of pushing little girls around, for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Why don't you get the fuck out of here, while I'll still let you.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: That's right, bitch.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What makes you spooks think you can bully a couple kids with impunity?

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What?! Are you fucking crazy? 37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 37 37 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Look at me, Slick. You're crazy if you thinking I'm fooling around.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: You are fucking crazy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have to be pretty goddamned dumb to think you can push people around without running into someone who will push back. The black guys are a bit dumbfounded. Walt stares them down.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: But you might just be dumb enough not to recognize that your luck just ran out. All bravado drains away from the black guys. Walt is a rock. Walt grins slightly and spits on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TALL BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Fuck this guy. He ain't worth it. The trio walks slowly across the street, forcing a car to miss a green light. Trey puts his hand out to shake Walt's...

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Man, thanks a lot, mister. Walt doesn't extend a hand, he lets Trey stand there like an idiot. Trey slowly lowers his arm. Walt looks at Trey's outfit.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Go home, clown... and pull up your goddamned pants. Walt turns to Sue.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll give you a ride. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 38 Walt and Sue drive in silence. Finally Sue speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: So, what's with you, you have some sort of savior complex or something?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What in the hell's the matter with you? I thought all you Asian girls were supposed to be so smart. What are you doing walking around in that neighborhood? That's how you end up in the obituaries, that is, if they can identify your body once they pull it out of the goddamned river.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Take it easy. Walt looks at her for a second. She's not ruffled at all. They drive.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So, that goofball back there. He's your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, kind of, his name is Trey.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why in the hell would you go out with a clown like that. Why don't you date one of your... own...one of those other... Hu-mungs.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You mean, Hmong? We're Hmong, not Hu-mung.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Right. Hmong. What is a... where is Hmong or whatever? Sue laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Wow! You're so enlightened. Hmong isn't a place, it's a people. 39. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 41
dialogues.text: Hmong people come from different parts of Laos and Thailand and China.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Then why are you in my neighborhood, instead of back there?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's a Vietnam thing. We fought on your side and when America quit, the Communists starting killing the Hmong, so we came over here. Walt is quiet for few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why'd you pick the Midwest, for Christ's sake? There's snow on the ground near half the year. Jungle people on the frozen tundra?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hill people. We were hill people, not jungle people. Boo-ga, boo- ga, boo-ga.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Blame the Lutherans. They brought us here.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Still, you'd think the cold would keep all the assholes away. Sue laughs again at Walt's conscienceless racism.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sure... You know, you seem okay. What the hell's the matter with your half-wit brother? He a little slow or something? 40.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Tao is actually really bright, he just doesn't know which direction to go in.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh, poor Toad.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's really common. Hmong girls over here fit in better, we adjust. The girls go to college, the boys go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 39 Walt drinks coffee and reads the newspaper. He flips from section to section. Daisy's at his feet. Next door, Phong sits watching Walt. He can see her mumbling under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Old hag, giving me the evil eye? Walt opens the paper to the TV guide section and lingers at the HOROSCOPES for a second.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Aw, what the hell... Walt reads aloud to himself.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Your birthday today; This year you have to make a choice between two life paths. Second chances come your way. Extraordinary events culminate in what might seem to be an anti-climax. Your lucky numbers are: 84, 23, 11, 78 and 99. Walt drains his coffee and tosses the paper onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What a load of crap. Walt lights up a cigarette and exhales. Walt watches as the only white woman on the block struggles to unload her groceries from her car. One of her bags rips. 41.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 38 38 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 43
dialogues.text: Three teenagers walk past and laugh at her spilled groceries. One of them makes a crude gesture behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Christ all Friday. What's wrong with kids today? Walt gets up to go help, but before he can get to the sidewalk, another neighbor has gone over to help... It's TAO. Tao bends down and carries her bags up to her door.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 40 Mitch and Karen sit across from Walt. A small store- bought birthday cake sits in front of Walt. Walt reads his birthday card. It's signed; Love Mitch, Karen, Ashley and Josh. ALL the signatures have been written in a woman's cursive style and with the same pen. Mitch slides a wrapped gift across the table to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Dad. Open it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Just open it. Walt opens the package, it's a Gopher Reaching Tool -- the kind that has an alligator clamp so you can pick up objects that have fallen behind the stove, etc. Walt looks at his son and daughter-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: It's a Gopher. It's so you can reach stuff. You know, it makes things easier.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Here's one from me. KAREN slides over a another wrapped gift. Walt opens it. It's a PHONE with really big numbers for old people. 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 39 39 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It's a phone.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (EMOTIONLESSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Karen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I just thought... we thought that it would... make things easier.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I see that.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with making things less hard on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Karen's right, Dad. You've worked hard your whole life. Maybe you should think about taking it a little easier? Walt lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: And that's another thing, Dad. You should get rid of the coffin nails. Walt says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: And the house, now that Mom's gone, it's got to be a lot to maintain, let alone clean... and you're all alone in here. It's worse than Walt thought. He puffs smoke.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: There's these great places now, these communities where you don't have to worry about mowing the lawn or shoveling snow. People who are like you, alert, active, but are alone and would benefit by being with other folks their own age. 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 40 40 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Dad, take a look. We brought some pamphlets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 41 Mitch and Karen storm out to their Land Cruiser. Mitch carries the Gopher Grabber Tool and Karen has the big numbered phone in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I told you, I told you this was a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I know, you were right.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! He just won't let anyone help him.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, we tried. Now we can just drop it. No one can say we didn't try.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: To hell with him, kicking us out on his birthday?! We should've stayed home with Ashley and Josh. They knew better, they wouldn't even come. The goddamned kids are smarter than we are! Mitch screeches the tires as they take off. Walt waits for them to clear out, before coming out on the porch with a can of Pabst. Daisy comes out and lies at his feet. Walt covers his mouth as he coughs. A dime-sized circle of dark, red blood is left in the palm of his hand. Walt looks at the blood as he takes another sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 42 Walt continues to sit on his porch, a long row of empty Pabst beer cans are lined up on the railing. 44.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 40 40 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 46
dialogues.text: Walt looks at a photo in his wallet, his and Dorothy's wedding photo. Walt looks down at Daisy --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: We miss Momma, don't we, Daisy. A vehicle pulls up to Tao's house. A party is in full swing. Sue comes out and helps the Hmong women unload big platters of food and carry them to the house. Sue catches Walt's gaze and steps over to his porch.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hey, Walt, what are you up to? Walt points his index finger at the can of Pabst in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We're having a barbecue. You want to come over?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: There's tons of food.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll bet. Just keep your paws off my dog.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No worries, we only eat cats.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, I'm kidding, you moron. Come on, come on over. You can be my special guest.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm fine right here. Walt reaches into the cooler for another beer. It's empty, just water and ice.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. 45.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 42 42 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What have you had to eat today, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: A piece of cake and some beef jerky.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Come on over and get something to eat. We've got beer, too. Walt exhales loudly --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh, what the hell. It's my birthday, I may as well drink with strangers instead of myself. Walt gets up and walks with Sue towards her house.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Wally.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't call me Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 43 Inside are thirty Hmong and Walt, who sticks out like a sore thumb. Total fish out of water. Walt looks in the refrigerator, Sue looks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You do have a lot of beer, but no Pabst.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: As they say, When in Hmong.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Ha ha. Are you sure it's okay I'm here? Everyone keeps looking at me and when I look back, they look at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's fine. Phong appears from the crowd and points at Walt. 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 42 42 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, get out. Out of our house! (to Sue) What is he doing here? Walt cringes at her presence.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: She said welcome to our home.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is this white man in our home? A man like him brings nothing, nothing but sorrow and death. Several relatives usher Phong away from Walt. The relatives are embarrassed at the outburst.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: She hates me.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yes, she hates you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What did I do? A little Hmong girl walks past and Walt pats her on the head. Everyone in the room looks in horror at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?! What the hell are all you fish heads looking at?! Sue looks around and then pulls Walt out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should go in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 44 Sue explains a few facts to Walt. 47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 43 43 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: A lot of the people in this house are very traditional. Number one, never touch a Hmong person on the head, not even a child. Hmong people believe that the soul resides in the head, so don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's dumb, but fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hmong people also consider looking someone in the eye to be rude. That's why everyone looks away when you look at them.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Swell. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, some Hmong smile or grin when they're yelled at or get into a confrontation. It's a cultural thing. It expresses embarrassment or insecurity, not that they're laughing at you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good God, you people are all nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 45 Walt opens another beer, as Sue speaks Hmong to a relative. Walt notices an Old Hmong Man staring at him. Walt interrupts Sue.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You said you guys don't look you in the eye, but that guy keeps staring at me. Sue laughs and gestures to the Old Hmong Man. The Old Hmong Man steps over and nods to Walt. 48.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 44 44 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: This is Kor Khue. He's the Lor family shaman.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Witch doctor? Sue smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Something like that. The Hmong hold their clan Shaman in very high regards.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Boo-ga, boo-ga. Kor Khue says something to Sue in Hmong. She turns and translates to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Kor Khue is interested in you, he heard what you did. He says he would like to read you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He wants to read you. Tell you your soul. It'd be rude not to allow him this, it's a great honor.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Tell Kor to be my guest, fire away. Sue speaks Hmong to the Shaman. The Shaman responds and sits down across from Walt. He looks at Walt for a long time. Walt stares straight back at him. The Shaman mumbles to himself. Finally the Shaman turns to Sue and speaks very rapidly. As Sue translates, the Shaman watches Walt's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Kor Khue says that you think you've been disrespected. You do not live your life. Your food has no flavor. You are scared of your past. 49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 45 45 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 51
dialogues.text: You stopped living years and years ago. Kor Khue says you're not at peace. Walt looks like he's been hit by a truck. The Shaman watches Walt closely, he knows he hit the nail on the head. Walt looks pale. He's been spooked good. He wipes sweat from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Walt gets up and steps into the kitchen. He takes several deep breaths. He's pretty shook up.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Je -- zuz -- Christ. Walt looks around at all the Hmongs eating and carrying on. Walt sees a young man give up his seat to an Elder. Walt sees a young woman go to each of the older folks and offer tea and cookies from a tray. Walt sees a child help an old man out of the bathroom. Walt coughs hard. He wipes blood from his lips. Sue comes in and looks at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Walt brushes past her and goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 46 EPIPHANY. Walt washes his face in the sink and dries his hands. He's still pale. He looks long and hard in the mirror. Walt is stunned, it all adds up. Walt hasn't really lived in 50 years, he hasn't relaxed or exhaled or let his guard down since he got back from Korea in 1953.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (to himself) Son of a bitch. I've got more in common with these goddamned gooks than my own spoiled-rotten family. 50.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 52
dialogues.text: Walt looks at himself.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Happy birthday. Walt opens the bathroom door. Sue stands there with a concerned look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Me? I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You were bleeding? Walt smiles disarmingly.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I just bit my tongue. I'm fine. I'm great. Let's get some of that gook food, I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 47 Walt sits amongst several old Hmong Women, who take great delight in feeding him different Hmong dishes which he's obviously never tasted before. Walt reacts with great enthusiasm to the food, occasionally making jokes like he's choking, etc. This corny stuff goes over like gangbusters with the Hmong ladies. Sue comes in and rolls her eyes at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Come on, you glutton, let's go downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: To mingle.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm fine right here. I'm mingling.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Come on, you said В‘not to leave you alone.' 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 48 Walt and Sue descend the stairway. Walt is really out of his element down with all the Hmong teenagers. And the first person he sees across the room is Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, look who's over there.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's-his-name who tried to steal my Gran Torino.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My brother Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Toad. Tao is in the corner, he avoids Walt's gaze. Sue walks over to a group of boys, leaving Walt alone. Walt doesn't know what to do with himself. He leans against the DRYER. The DRYER wobbles. Walt gets on his hands and knees. He looks under the dryer. He adjusts the short leg to balance out the machine. He just can't help it. All the Hmong kids watch Walt, trying not to laugh at this strange white man on his hands and knees fixing a dryer during a party. Walt looks up -- deer in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It was wobbly, but I fixed it. It's fine now, shouldn't wobble anymore. The Hmong kids look away, covering their mouths with their hands. Walt glares at Tao, who immediately wipes the smile from his face. Sue walks over and hands Walt a drink.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's this? 52. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Rice liquor. Try it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Alright. Sue walks off. Walt sips his rice liquor and watches the interaction between the boys and girls. One particularly gorgeous young willow-wisp of a GIRL stares across the room at Tao. Tao looks back at her, but then looks away. The Girl keeps looking at Tao, smiling and twisting her hair. Tao doesn't approach her, but three other young men do. They do their best to charm her. She's polite, but not interested, she keeps looking at Tao. Walt laughs at Tao's ineptitude, shakes his head at this wasted opportunity. Suddenly the Girl steps over to Walt. She smiles --

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM, (GIRL)
dialogues.text: My friends and I were just wondering what you're doing here?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good question. What am I doing here? Anyways, I'm Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: Hi, Walt. I'm Wa Xam.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wa Yum?

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: No, Wa Xam. So... what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Me? Not too much... I fix stuff I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, I fixed my wife's friend's sink yesterday. 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 48 48 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 55
dialogues.text: I drove my aunt to the doctor to straighten out her prescription. Even fixed my screen door before it was broke.

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: You're funny.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's one thing I've never been accused of. A bastard, yes. Funny, no. Wa Xam laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: Well, have fun. I'm going to take off.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you, Yum Yum. She laughs at Walt butchering her name and goes upstairs. The three young suitors follow her up. Tao watches her. Walt comes over to Tao, who is startled. Walt laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Relax, zipper head, whatta you think I'm gonna do, shoot you? Tao looks like he wants to run away.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say anything either, if I was you. Walt sips his rice liquor. Walt can't help but rib Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You know, I knew you were a dipshit even before the whole garage deal, but I have to say you're even worse with women than you are stealing cars, Toad.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: It's Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: It's Tao, not Toad. My name is Tao. 54.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good for you. Anyways, you're blowing it with that girl. Not that I give two shits about a Toad like you.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wrong, egg roll. I completely know what I'm talking about. I know I'm not always the most pleasant person to be around, but I got the greatest woman who ever lived to marry me. I had to work at it, but I got her and it was the best thing that ever happened to me. Hands down. Walt points across the room. He sways slightly.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: But you? You just sit there and watch as Ding Dong and Click Clack and Charlie Chan walk away with what's-her-face. She likes you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: She was standing over there, orange dress, twisting her hair and smiling at you.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You mean Wa Xam? Walt takes a long swig off his drink and nods.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Anyways, she likes you, I know, I talked to her. Great girl, charming girl. Love her. I love Yum Yum. But you? You just watch her walk out the door with the Three Stooges. Why? Because you're a big fat pussy! Walt drains his drink. 55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 48 48 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I gotta go home. Good luck, puss- cake. You need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 49 Walt empties the lawnmower bag as two elderly Hmong Women come over, each carrying a FLOWER BOUQUET.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. No thanks. No more flowers. The elderly Hmong Women nod and speak rapid sentences in Hmong to Walt. He has no idea what they are saying.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No more. Please, keep your flowers. The Hmong women nod, smile and chatter away, ignoring Walt. They walk past him and set the BOUQUETS on his porch.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (DEFEATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just put them on the porch. But that's it. No more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 50 The doorbell rings. Walt answers, a Skillsaw in one hand. Standing on his doorstep are three Hmong women.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What now, Gee? Gee holds up a plate covered with tinfoil.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. Forget it. Stop bringing me stuff. Gee scolds Walt in Hmong.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. I've had it. Gee opens the corner of the tinfoil. Walt looks at the food. 56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 48 48 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I can't. You have to stop. Gee pulls the tinfoil off. Walt gazes at the food.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that the chicken dumpling thing you brought the other day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 51 Walt pulls up in his pickup truck. Sue and Vu wait on Walt's porch. Tao stands out on the sidewalk. Walt gets out of his pickup.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What now? What? Vu rambles on in Hmong. Walt looks at his watch. He looks at Sue for the translation.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Tao is here to make amends, he's here to work for you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No he's not.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Mother says that Tao dishonored the family and now he has to work off his debt. He'll start tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. The kid is useless, I don't even want him on my property. I thought we already went over that.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
