dialogues.text: It's very important to my mother that you accept. It'd be an insult to refuse.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How is this all of a sudden turned around on me? The goddamned kid tries to steal my car and somehow I'm the bad guy if I don't accept? 57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 50 50 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My family is very traditional and it will very much upset them if you don't let Tao repay... Tao interrupts from the sidewalk...

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Come on, Sue. If he doesn't want to, let's just go. Sue and Vu yell at Tao to shut up at the same time; Sue in English, Vu in Hmong.

dialogues.speaker: SUE/VU
dialogues.text: Shut up. Shut up! Shut up!! Tao looks at the ground. A PAUSE. Walt sees the earnest looks on the Hmong women's faces. Their expression В“begsВ” Walt. Walt gazes back at Tao. Walt looks disgusted, he exhales loudly...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Fine. Great. Tomorrow. Walt walks past them and into his house.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus, Joseph and Mary. These Hmong broads are like badgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 52 Walt sits drinking coffee and reading the newspaper. Tao walks sheepishly over to the property line.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch, I didn't think he'd show. Walt waves Tao over. Tao barely looks at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay. What are you good at?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's what I'm asking. What are you good at? 58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 51 51 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 60
dialogues.text: If you're gonna work for me, I have to know what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's about what I expected. Okay, why don't you go over by the spruce tree and count how many birds feed at the bird feeder.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Count the birds?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can count? You slopes are supposed to be good at math, right?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yes, I can count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 53 Tao stands in Walt's garden with his arms folded. Walt walks over to trim weeds around the garden fence. Walt doesn't even look at Tao. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You want me to do that?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I want it done right, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: But you've got me just standing here. What am I supposed to be doing, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Scaring away crows. Tao shoots Walt a dirty look. 59.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It's a perfect job for you, plus you people don't seem to mind squinting in the sun all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 54 Walt waters a flower bed. Tao comes over and stands there. Walt finishes watering before even looking at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What do you have for me today? You want me to watch paint dry or maybe count the clouds that pass by?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't get flip with me, zipper head. I ain't the one who tried to steal and don't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I don't care if you insult me and say racist things. I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That I know. You have no teeth, kid. That's your problem. You have no balls.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Look, I'm stuck here. Why don't you give me something useful to do.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Because unlike you I'm not useless. I maintain my property, whereas you swamp rats let your houses go to hell. Walt looks across the street at one very dilapidated house.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... How long do I have you for? Tao pauses... he doesn't want to answer.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How long, Toad? 60.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 53 53 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till next Friday. Walt laughs out loud. It makes Tao cringe.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Go get my ladder out of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 55 Tao is at the top of the LADDER. Walt and the Hmong neighbor grin at him from the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: When you're done caulking the siding, nail that gutter back up, I can see it right out my kitchen window, it's been bugging me for three years. The neighbor says something in Hmong to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You said it, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 56 Tao digs up a big TREE STUMP out in the rain. It's hard, draining labor and Tao is covered with mud. Tao's shovel hits rocks and roots and clay. Misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 57 We see Tao do various chores; scrape paint, hang screen doors, reattach house numbers, trim bushes, etc. Walt scrutinizes his every move. Tao is a virtual slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 58 Walt watches with great satisfaction as Tao paints one of the neighboring houses. The neighborhood is really shaping up. Walt sips his coffee with a slight grin. He is really, really, really enjoying this. 61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 54 54 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 63
dialogues.text: A very old Hmong man and his very young GRANDSON walk up Walt's driveway. The Grandson translates for grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDSON
dialogues.text: Grandpa says he want to know if you can have Tao clear out the big wasp nest under our porch? Walt reaches in his pocket and studies a small note pad.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't see why not. (GRINS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him sometime after lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 59 Tao walks up the sidewalk. Before ringing the doorbell, Tao looks down at his hands which have several CALLOUSES on them. Tao rubs his hands with a smile. This has been the first time Tao has really risen to a task presented to him. Tao reaches for the doorbell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 60 Walt stands over the sink, coughing. In the b.g. the doorbell rings. Walt coughs up a big spot of blood, it's thick with fibers. The doorbell rings again. Walt wipes his mouth and runs the water in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 61 Walt answers the door, just as Tao rings the doorbell a third time. Walt looks angry.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Lord almighty, knock it off.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: It's my last day, whatta you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Take the day off, you've done enough. 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 58 58 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 64
dialogues.text: Tao looks disappointed, but says nothing. He nods and starts to walk away. Walt calls after him...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Toad. Tao turns around. Walt wants to say something, but stops.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nothing, never mind. Walt shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 62 Walt sits in the crowded waiting room. He looks around. He's the only WHITE PERSON in the room. Even most of the STAFF is African or from India. As Walt waits, names are called out such as Alvarez, Ngaima, Yang and Abdalla. Finally when the name В“KowalskiВ” is called, the Muslim woman can't pronounce it correctly. Walt winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 63 Walt sits in a chair, his hands folded in his lap. A short Asian man in a doctor's smock comes in with a chart.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Kowalski?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. I looked over your paperwork and I think we should immediately start on a full battery of tests. I feel that this...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where's my regular doctor, where's Dr. Fellman? 63.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 61 61 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Dr. Fellman retired three years ago. I'm his replacement, Dr. Chang.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 64 Mitch, Karen and Ashley are in the kitchen. The phone rings and Ashley looks at the caller ID.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: It's Grandpa Walt.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: You talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I'm doing bills here.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's your father. Ashley hands him the phone and he pushes the TALK button.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hello, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello? It's me... Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I know. What's up? The CAMERA INTERCUTS BETWEEN Mitch in his huge kitchen and Walt sitting on the edge of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Um... not much, how about you?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I'm fine, fine.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Fine. That's fine... How about the kids and Karen? 64.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 63 63 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Everyone is fine.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good. There is a long, uncomfortable pause. Walt looks at some Xeroxed medical pamphlets scattered on his bed.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, that's good... How's... work?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Busy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Right. I s'pose.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Speaking of busy, I have a lot on my plate right now, unless there's something pressing. Walt looks at a pale, blue pamphlet. Mitch looks at his housekeeping bill.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. Nope. Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Okay. Yeah, so it's not a good time right now. Why don't you call me over the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Okay, it was nice talking to you, bye, Dad. Walt hangs up. He lies down on his bed. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 65 While Walt fills a bird feeder, he notices Tao next door. Tao stands, tiptoed on the top of a six-foot ladder, trying to cut a high branch with a pole saw. Walt shakes his head and walks over to Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey, moron. Tao is startled and almost falls off the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I appreciate you're doing something on your own, but you're the only person I know dumb enough to get himself killed trimming tree branches.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You don't stand on the top step of a ladder and if you cut through that branch you're hacking away at, you'll end up kaput. Tao looks and sure enough -- a thick, black POWER LINE is five feet below the branch he's almost severed.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Go grab the extension ladder from my garage and I'll show you how to do it right, zipper head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 66 Tao ties up bundles of branches and twigs. Walt lights a cigarette, looks up in the tree and nods.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Looks good. Good job. Tao nods. 66. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Make sure you put the ladder back when you're done raking up the leaves.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I know. I will. Walt walks back over to his porch, grabs a Pabst from the cooler and watches Tao rake. A white Honda turns the corner and drives slowly past Tao. Smokie and Spider smile menacingly at Tao as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: This kid doesn't have a chance. The Honda now slowly passes Walt's house. Walt just stands there, sipping his beer. The Honda slows to a stop and the gangbangers glare at Walt. The REAR WINDOW of the Honda opens. Walt holds out his RIGHT HAND like a GUN. He closes one eye to better В“aimВ” his imaginary gun and moves his thu several times as if firing. Bang -- bang -- bang. The Honda takes off. Walt watches it drive off and lights another cigarette. Walt doesn't notice, but Tao witnessed this whole interaction from his yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 67 The doorbell rings. Walt opens his door. Tao stands there with his hands in his pockets. He's a bit apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What do you know about faucets? Walt stares at him for a second and then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 68 Tao looks on as Walt turns the faucet on and off, it drips water at its base. Walt looks under the sink.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: For the love of Pete.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It must be a hundred degrees in here, turn on the fan. Tao flips the switch on the CEILING FAN, the fan wobbles and shakes, it looks like it's about to fly off. Walt stares up at the fan and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 69 The CEILING FAN and FAUCET are taken apart on the workbench. Walt reinstalls the diverter valve. Tao looks at all of Walt's tools.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Man, where did you get all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: All the tools and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Where the hell do you think I got them, Toad? This may come as a shock to a thief, but I actually bought the things I have with money I earned.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, that's not what I meant. There's just so much shit packed in here.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You need the right tool for the right job. Every single thing here has a purpose. 68. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Okay, what's this? Tao points to a tool.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Post hole digger. Tao starts pointing at things on the workbench in quick succession, questioning Walt with his expression.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hand spade. Tin snips. Nail punch. Tack hammer. Putty knife. Wire stripper. Drywall saw. Tile spacers. Silence. Walt can see something is bothering Tao, but he's too uncomfortable to speak up --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I can't afford to buy all this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I didn't buy all this stuff at once, blockhead. I've lived here for fifty years. A man stays in one place long enough he tends to attract a decent set of tools.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yeah, but...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Look, kid, I think I know where you're going with this. You don't need everything to maintain a house. I'm going to let you in on a little secret. Walt rattles around his tool bench and slaps down THREE items in quick succession.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: This is for you. Roll of duct tape, can of WD-40 and a pair of vise-grips. Any man who's worth a shit can do half his household jobs with these three things. In the odd chance that doesn't work out, you can borrow something. 69.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 69 69 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool. Walt coughs and covers his mouth. Both Tao and Walt see the spot of BLOOD in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What's with that?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's with what?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: The blood you just coughed up. That's not good, you should see a doctor. Walt quickly changes the subject -- while tightening the screws that hold the fan blade to the motor hub.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So... what exactly was the deal with those guys out on my lawn that night? Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: A gang. Hmong gangbangers.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I gathered that. What did they want with you?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: They wanted to take me away because I blew my first initiation.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You joined up with those pukes? Damn, you are a pussy. Why in the hell did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I don't know. They were persuasive. My cousin's in the gang. They just talked me into it I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, at least you're honest about it. A LONG SILENCE. Walt finishes fixing the ceiling fan. 70.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 69 69 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So how'd you blow your first initiation? Tao nods towards the GRAN TORINO.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: The Gran Torino? Tao nods. Walt laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Christ all Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 70 Walt straps an old WESTINGHOUSE FREEZER onto a two- wheeled DOLLY. Walt attempts to pull the freezer upstairs. Walt strains with the heavy appliance. It's too much weight for Walt, but this doesn't stop him from heaving and pulling. Walt could have done this by himself when he was younger. Walt sits down on the step and breathes hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 71 Mitch watches afternoon baseball, drinking an imported, bottled beer. KAREN pokes her head into the room.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: See you later, I'm taking the kids to the mall. Mitch never looks up from the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine. Just don't spend too much goddamned money.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I will. We hear Karen and the kids exit.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Thank God. Finally get the house to myself for once. The PHONE RINGS. Mitch looks at the Caller ID. It says; В“Dad.В” Mitch almost doesn't pick it up... 71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 69 69 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello? It's me, Dad... Walt.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad. What's up? The CAMERA INTERCUTS BETWEEN Walt in his small kitchen and Mitch in his huge den.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well... I... um... I'm getting the old Westinghouse up out of the basement. Mitch mouths the word В“Shit.В”

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So... I got it on the dolly.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, that'll help.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah... And it's a bit heavy... for one guy.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah... I need a hand.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So are you busy?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Does it have to be done right this second? It's been down there for years.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well... Yeah, I'd like to get on it. 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 71 71 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Does it work? We were thinking about getting a freezer. What are you going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Giving it to Aunt Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Oh... Can't she give you a hand?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: She's eighty-one.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I know, I was joking... What does she need it for?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: To freeze food. Mitch opens another beer.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I'd love to help you out, Dad, but I'm just walking out the door. I have to bring the kids to the mall. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Why don't you call Stevie?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Your brother lives out of state.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know what to tell you, I'm on my way out. Keys in my hand.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: If you can't find anyone by next week, give me a call. Walt nods and hangs up. Mitch hangs up and takes a sip of beer. 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 71 71 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Aunt Mary. Like she needs a freezer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 72 The doorbell rings and Tao opens the door. There stands Walt. Tao is a little shocked.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You got a minute, Toad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 73 Walt and Tao look at the freezer strapped to the dolly.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I just need a little push. All the weight is up top, so you stay down and give me a little shove at each step.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Let me take the top.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Naw, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No really, I'll take the top. It looks pretty heavy.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm not crippled. I got it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: If you don't let me take the top, I ain't helping. I'll go home.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Listen, zipper head, now's not the time to go and...

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You listen, old man. You came and got me because you needed help, so let me help you. Either it's top or I'm out of here. Walt studies Tao for a second. Tao doesn't blink, he holds his ground. Walt nods, trying not to grin. 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 71 71 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay then, be my guest. Just don't let it slip out of your little girl hands and crush me. Tao laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Don't give me any ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 74 Tao and Walt ease the freezer down the back steps and pause to take a break. They both breathe hard.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: That thing weighs a ton.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it runs like new. They don't make them like that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sell it. I haven't used it in years and it was always in the way down there.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Sixty bucks, maybe. Why, you need a freezer?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our downstairs one died. Walt thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Twenty-five and it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Twenty-five? You just said sixty?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Save me from wasting money on putting an ad in the paper. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 75 Walt and Sue sit eating Laab as they watch Tao, who washes and waxes the Gran Torino in Walt's driveway. Sue laughs and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Kind of ironic, huh?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think I'm referring to? Toad washing the car he tried to steal from you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It seems like justice to me. And if he misses a spot, he's doing it all over.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's nice of you to kind of look after him like this. He doesn't have any real role models in his life.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I ain't a role model.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Wally. I wish our dad would have been more like you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't call me Wally.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious. He was hard on us, really traditional, really old school.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm old school.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you're American.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? Sue shrugs him off. They look at Tao for awhile. 76. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You like him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Him? Don't be crazy. He tried to steal my car.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: And you spend time with him and you teach him how to fix things and you saved him from that fuck cousin of ours and...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey. Watch the language.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: And you're a good man.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hand me a beer, Dragon Lady. Sue hands him a beer and Walt pops the top.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So tell me the problem with Hmong boys again. I'm not completely clear.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hmong girls slip in and out of the culture more easily. Date who we want, stay close to our mothers, but are able to keep a foot on each side of the fence. The boys fall through the cracks.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's tough. The boys float around. The fathers belong in a totally different world and the boys have no one to turn to. Does that make sense?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not sure. No.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: The boys don't ask their fathers for advice, because over here, their fathers no longer have the answers. 77.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 75 75 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 79
dialogues.text: Hmong boys become almost invisible, they end up banding together and it all goes to hell from there.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: The girls go to college and the boys go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's more common than not. Walt reflects on this for awhile, then changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You still going out with that clown?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No. I dumped him. He was a dim- wit. Walt nods.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 76 Walt and Tao spread mulch around Walt's vegetable plants.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You know, the Hmong consider gardening to be women's work.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that why I see you out in your garden all the time? Besides, zipper head, we ain't in Hu-Mong.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Funny. Walt lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You should quit those. It's bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So is joining a gang, you dipshit. 78.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Seriously, you should quit, I saw you cough up blood.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So, you ever think about what you want to do with your life?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You've never thought about it?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Of course I have.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, while you're thinking about it, try not to stomp all over my chives, you dipshit. Tao looks down; sure enough, he's standing on Walt's chives.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Put some mulch around the cucumbers. Tao spreads more mulch.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I was thinking about sales, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: My oldest son's a salesman. He sells cars.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Does he do well?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: License to steal. I worked in a Ford plant for thirty years and my son sells goddamned Japanese cars.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You made cars? 79.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 76 76 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's right. And I put the steering column in the Gran Torino when it rolled down the line in 1972.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Wow, that's cool.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Does your son come over much?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How are you going about getting into sales? You thinking about school?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Kinda.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, you should.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: School costs money.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Maybe you should get a job and save instead of spreading mulch in my garden.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Maybe you could just pay me.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What kind of job could I get?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good question. Who the hell would hire you?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (DEFLATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Aw, go on. I'm kidding. You could get a job, easy. 80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 76 76 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'd think about construction.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Me? Construction? What, do you have Alzheimer's or something?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Naw, you could hack it. You just need a little adjustment.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You said yourself I'm worthless and I have soft little girl hands.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's exactly the point. I know some guys in the trades, but you have to get your shit together. We have to man you up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Man me up?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yes. And you should ask out Yum Yum too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 77 Walt and Tao walk up to the barbershop.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have to learn how guys talk. Now watch how me and Martin communicate. We just throw it back and forth. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go in. Walt holds the door for Tao and they enter. The Barber has his feet up reading a Playboy.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Oh great, a Pollack and a chink. 81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 76 76 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Martin, you dumb Italian prick.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Walt, you cheap asshole, I should have known you'd come in, I was having such a pleasant day.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why, did you jew some blind man out of a few bucks, give him the wrong change? Walt and the Barber shake hands warmly. Tao is wide- eyed.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Who's the Nip?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: This is Tao. He's a pussy kid who lives next door and I'm trying to man him up a little. Walt points at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Did you see? That's how men talk to each other.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: What, do you have shit in your ears?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay. You go out, come back in and give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Come on, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I said go out there, come back in and talk to the barber like a man. Do it. Tao shrugs, goes outside, lets the door shut then comes back in. The Barber stands there with a sneer on his face. 82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 77 77 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Wus up, you old Italian prick? The Barber levels a sawed-off SHOTGUN at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Get outta my shop before I blow your head off, you long-haired faggy little gook! Tao is terrified, frozen stiff. Walt and the Barber throw their heads back and laugh. The Barber lowers the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Toad, you don't walk in and insult a guy. What are you, an idiot?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: But... but that's what you said. That's what you said men say.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not if you never met the guy. If you say that shit to the wrong stranger, they'll blow your goddamned gook head off! Walt and the Barber laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What should I have said?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Anything but that.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Kid, you shoulda just started with В‘Hi' or В‘Hello.'

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Right. You should have said, В‘Excuse me, I'm looking for a haircut if you have time.'

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Be polite, but don't kiss ass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Or, even better is act like you just got off a construction job. 83.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 77 77 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 85
dialogues.text: Or bitch about your girlfriend or getting your car fixed.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Right. Son of a bitch, I just got my brakes fixed and those sons a bitches really nailed me. Screwed me right in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Exactly. Don't swear at the guy you're talking to, swear about another guy who ain't there. My son of a bitch prick fucking boss made me work overtime and he knew I had bowling tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Or, my old lady bitches to me for two fucking hours about how they don't take expired coupons at the grocery store and the minute I turn on the goddamned game, she starts crying how we never talk.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: See? You come back in, Toad. Be polite and then you bring up something you can both talk about. It ain't rocket science.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don't have a job or a car or a girlfriend. Walt and the Barber laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus, I shoulda blown his head off when I had the chance.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Just go back outside and try it again. And don't mention you're a pussy with no car, girl, job, future or whatever. Come in and act like a man, Toad. Tao goes out, turns around and comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, I need a haircut, if you ain't too busy... you Italian son-of-a-bitch prick barber. 84.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 86
dialogues.text: Walt and the Barber laugh...

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Boy does my ass hurt from all the guys at my construction job. Walt and the Barber laugh harder.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: If you do this, you're going to follow through, right?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, not yeah, yeah. Yes, as in yes, sir, I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You better, because when I vouch for someone, it's my word and I don't want anyone making me look bad.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No, I'm good. I'm totally into this.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And don't lay down to people all the time. Always look a person in the eye. When you shake a man's hand, you can usually tell where you stand with him. Walt hands a pair of beat-up WORK GLOVES to Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Here, stuff these in your back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Just don't blow this. 85.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 77 77 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 87
dialogues.text: Walt and Tao walk up to the Superintendent's Office Trailer on a construction job site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 79 Walt and Tao come in. Walt shakes hands with TIM KENNEDY, the job super.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Kennedy, you drunken Irish goon, how the hell are ya?

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Shitty, but who's gonna listen?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not me. Walt pours himself a cup of the bad job-site coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Help yourself, Walt, you dumb Pollack.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I already did. This is the kid I told you about. Tao, this is Tim Kennedy, he's the super on the job. Kennedy looks Tao up and down. Tao looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: What do we got, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He's done construction here and there. Whatever you need, he'll pick it up quick.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You speak English?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You born here? 86.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 78 78 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You got a vehicle? I see Walt drove you here.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Not at the moment. I'm taking the bus for now.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: The bus? Jesus Christ, you don't have a car?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: My headgasket cracked and the goddamned prick at the shop wants to bend me over for $2100.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: I just replaced the tranny in my Tahoe and the sons a bitches fucked me hard, just under $3200.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Goddamned thieves. It ain't right.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You got that right. Come on in on Monday and we'll find something for you to do. Tao puts out his hand to shake.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Kennedy. Tim Kennedy shakes Tao's hand.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: It's Tim. What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Tao.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Okay. You owe me one, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll send you a fucking fruitcake at Christmas. 87.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 79 79 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Fuck the fruitcake, why don't you hand over the keys to that Gran Torino.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, everybody seems to want that car.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You don't know the half of it. Come on, zipper head, let's let this big Mick get back to screwing off. Walt and Tao exit and walk back to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 80 Walt pulls into a Home Depot parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What are you gonna put all your tools in, an empty rice bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 81 Walt and Tao walk the aisles. Walt grabs a tool belt and tosses it to Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You'll need this. Walt then tosses Tao a utility knife holder.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And you'll need that. Now where the hell do they hide the hardware holders?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I can't afford any of this.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll get it, but you're paying me back with your first check. 88.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 79 79 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Cool. Walt pitches a hardware pouch at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And you need this too. That should about do it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Not to bitch, but won't I be needing some tools?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Tools I got, but I ain't loaning you my tool belt. You can buy tools as you go.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I appreciate all this.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Aw, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No, I really do. Thank you. Walt sticks out his jaw and looks Tao straight in the eye. Tao doesn't know what to expect. A PAUSE. Walt puts out his HAND to Tao. Tao extends his and they SHAKE HANDS. It's really quite a moment for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 82 Tao gets off the bus, his tool belt over his shoulder. Tao looks tired after working, but content. He walks past an abandoned lot. The tricked-out Honda pulls up and stops. Smokie, Spider and company get out. Tao looks nervous, but remains calm.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Just seeing what you're up to, cuz. 89.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 81 81 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I'm getting home from work, not that you guys would know much about that.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: So it's true? You got a job.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Come on, what do you guys want with me?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Tao. What do you think? I've been sooooo easy on you, but I can't just go on like nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You can't just leave me alone?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Afraid not. The gangbangers grab Tao. Tao kicks and struggles as they yank away his tool belt.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Keep your hands off my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Your stuff? You and everything you have is mine. I own you. Smokie pulls the tape measure off the belt and smashes it against the pavement. Whatever tools Smokie can't destroy, he tosses onto the roof of the closest building.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: You can't just walk away from us, Tao. It looks bad. It makes me look bad. Smokie lights a CIGARETTE and exhales...

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: What's the phrase I'm looking for? Oh yeah, I need to В‘save face.' Smokie grabs Tao by the neck and presses the lit CIGARETTE into Tao's cheek. Tao screams as his flesh burns. 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 83 Walt spots Tao as he takes out the trash.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey there. Tao looks to the ground and heads in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Hey, I gotta run.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where have you been, I haven't seen you in days?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Busy. Walt squints at Tao. He steps closer. Tao looks away. Walt tilts Tao's head up, he sees the burn.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What in the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it? Look at your goddamned face!

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I said don't worry about it. It's not your problem. Walt looks at the ground and spits.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Couple days ago. Grabbed me after I got off the bus coming home from work.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Cowards.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I did everything I could possibly do. They broke some of your tools. I'll replace them. 91. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Forget the tools. Where does your cousin live?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No, Walt, I can manage. I don't want you doing anything. Walt is angry, but eventually nods at Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Alright. You need any other tools for work?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I could use a roofing hammer.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Go in the garage and get whatever you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 84 Tao leans over his desk with a black Sharpie marker. He carefully writes В“Tao Vang LorВ” in black ink on the fac of his smashed-up tape measure. He puts it back into the tool belt and grabs another tool to label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 85 Walt sits in the dark, the only light is from the radio tuned to baseball. Daisy lies in the front seat. Next to Daisy is the M1 RIFLE. Walt watches as Spider and another Hmong gangbanger step out of the rundown duplex, get in their Honda and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's the last of them. Walt pulls out his Colt .45 automatic and chambers a round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 86 Walt pounds loudly on the door. A moment later the door starts to swing open and a voice is heard...

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell did... 92.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 83 83 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 94
dialogues.text: Walt kicks open the door and grabs Smokie by the collar. Walt drags the 105 pound Smokie out of his house and tosses him off the front porch onto the front sidewalk. Smokie is stunned. Walt kicks him hard in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: How the fuck did you get here?!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You aren't that hard to track down. Walt boots him again. Smokie curls up in the fetal position.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: What do you want? Walt kicks him a second time.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I came to give you a chance. SOMETHING comes out of the shadows under the porch. Walt swings the barrel of the big Colt .45 at the movement. It's a cat. Walt puts his pistol away. Smokie exhales.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It's just you and me. Nobody knows or has to know I was here. You lay off Tao. Tell your guys he ain't worth it or whatever the hell you want. You don't talk to him, you don't go near him. This is your one chance. You lay off and no one will ever be the wiser. Smokie says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll take that as a yes. I don't want to come back here. But if I do, believe me, it'll be goddamned ugly. Walt kicks Smokie again and stalks off into the dark. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 87 Walt pulls up his driveway and parks. Daisy jumps out and Walt carries his rifle into the house. Walt walks stiffly. Walt gets to the door and drops his keys. When he bends down to pick them up, you can really tell he's sore and hurting. Walt groans as he goes inside. He's feeling his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 88 Vu, Sue, Tao and Wa Xam all sit in lawn chairs, talking and laughing. Walt flips the inch-thick STEAKS on his Weber.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How do you want your dog... I mean steaks cooked? Medium, medium well?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Funny. Walt pops open a beer and grabs an appetizer that Vu made.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is this Hmoog or Laab?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Laab.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Isn't it usually a little spicier? Tao, Wa Xam and Sue laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh whatever, Wally.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: It does. Usually it's got more zing.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, look at you. I've never seen you like this.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What? 94. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Look at you smile, old man. Kicking back, having a good old time. You're sure pleased with yourself today.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: And it's a little unnerving if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Aw, go on.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, admit it. You are. You're feeling pretty good, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Well, who wouldn't? I'm surrounded by beautiful women, it's a beautiful day. Great food, good friends. Hell, even Toad isn't driving me nuts for once.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: It never ends.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding. Let me tell you something, Yum-Yum. If Tao doesn't ask you out soon, I will.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him, Wa Xam. He's a white devil.

dialogues.speaker: WA XAM
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, Walt, but he beat you to it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. Movie? Dinner? Wa Xam and Tao nod. They're a bit embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're taking the bus.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: The bus?! That's no good. A charming young lady like this deserves to go in style. 95.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 88 88 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Like what? Take a limo? Walt nods towards the GRAN TORINO.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: The Gran Torino? You'd let me drive it?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Really? Walt smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Really. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 89 Walt watches baseball. He hears a car outside. Shouts are heard and glass breaks. Walt gets up and looks out the shades... TAO'S HOUSE is raked with GUNFIRE coming from a VAN! Windows shatter and the siding splinters. FIFTY BULLETS shake the house before the VAN peels off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 90 Walt is up their front steps and in the house in seconds. Walt goes from room to room, from Vu to Phong finally to Tao -- making sure no one's been hit.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is everyone okay? Is anyone hit? Sue? Vu? Tao, where's Tao? Tao sits up from behind the couch. Blood pours down his neck. He's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh no. Walt lays Tao down and rips open the collar of his shirt. Walt probes around Tao's neck. 96.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 88 88 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hang on... you're just cut, is all.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Is everybody else okay?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Walt looks around at the BULLET HOLES in the walls. Tao follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: It's a miracle no one was killed.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: They aimed high. Sure enough -- most of the bullet holes are above head level on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Where's Sue?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: She went to our aunt's.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Call her.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I said call her. Get the goddamned phone and call and see if she's there. Tao scrambles for the phone and dials. Tao speaks Hmong to whomever answered. Tao starts to speak faster. He looks at Walt and shakes his head В“no.В For once -- Vu and Phong understand what Walt was talking about. There is anguish on every face in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 91 Walt sits across from Tao, drinking rice liquor. Walt speaks loudly, without any consideration for Phong who shoots him dirty looks.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: This is exactly what I didn't want. Damn gooks. Why the hell am I even here?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Maybe one of her friends called and she just changed plans. Walt sips the rice liquor. Walt now speaks quietly to Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: In Korea I learned not to care. The best friends of my life are still missing somewhere in Korea. You harden yourself. Don't let anything get to you. Phong looks out the window and screams. She runs over and swings open the door. Everyone expects the worst... And it comes like a cold wind -- SUE WALKS IN LIKE A ZOMBIE. She has been brutally beaten. Her clothes are dirty and torn. BLOOD runs down SUE'S legs from under her shirt. Walt looks at her and the glass falls from his hand. Sue staggers into Vu's arms. Vu weeps. Sue hugs her mother and sobs. Tao reaches to hug his sister, but Phong screeches at him, pointing at Walt and back to Tao. Walt is destroyed. He steps outside into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 92 Walt staggers across the yard to his house.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no. 98. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 100
dialogues.text: Walt bursts in the door, throws himself in an easy chair and CRIES. He tries to stop and cries harder. It's the first time Walt has cried in fifty years. He wails, crying for Tao, Sue, his wife, kids and himself. He lets it all out. Daisy jumps in his lap and he hugs his old dog as he bawls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 93 Walt sits, red-eyed. He's done crying. Family photo albums are scattered around. Father Janovich knocks and eases open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Mr. Kowalski, are you in here?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Come on in. Father Janovich comes in and sits down across from Walt.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Walt nods.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: The police finally left. No one is talking. One thing about the Hmong, they keep their mouths shut.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I've noticed that. Father Janovich picks up a photo album and flips through it. Pictures of Mitch and Steve as babies.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You know, there's no way that Tao or Sue are gonna have any peace if these gang guys don't go away. Go away forever. You know it as well as I do.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What are you saying? 99.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 92 92 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You heard what I said.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: They took Sue to the hospital. She's scared. They're all scared.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I know that. Believe me, they all know that. Tao especially. He's sitting out there staring at your front door. You know what he expects, Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well what would you do if you were me? If you were Tao? What would you do? Father Janovich shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I know what I'd do if I was you, or at least what you think you should do. If I was Tao I guess I'd want vengeance. I'd want to stand shoulder to shoulder with you and kill those guys.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What would I do? I'd come over here and talk to you I guess. I know you're close with these people, but this pisses me off too, Mr. Kowalski. Walt nods.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Wanna beer?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'd love one.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: They're in the cooler, grab me one too. 100.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 93 93 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 102
dialogues.text: Father Janovich grabs four beers, two for each of them. He opens a Pabst and takes a big swig.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Damn all this. It just isn't fair.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nothing's fair, Father. Father Janovich and Walt sit for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: So, what are you going to do, Mr. Kowalski?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Call me Walt. Father Janovich nods.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Alright, what are you going to do, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not sure yet. All I do know is they don't have a goddamned chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 94 Walt sits at the kitchen table in his robe, drinking coffee. Tao comes in without even knocking on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm thinking.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Thinking time is over. Now it's time to knock the ass out of those pricks.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know you don't want to hear this, but you have to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What?! 101.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 93 93 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have to have a clear head, otherwise mistakes get made. Back away from what's happened, Tao.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No. Don't let me down, Walt. Not you. This is going to end, today. Walt stands up and pulls out a chair for Tao to sit in.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I don't want to sit.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I SAID SIT DOWN! Just listen up for a second and don't say anything. Tao sits down. Walt rubs his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know what needs to be done. I need to prepare, this needs to be carefully planned. You know I'm the right man for this. So cool down for a little while and meet me back here at 4 P.M. I promise you, what needs to be done, will be done.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: I say we go now. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And do what? You want to go kill your cousin and those other Zips. Mr. Tough-Guy-All-Of-A-Sudden is out for blood. What do you even know about it? Tao is furious, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Trust me, Tao. Cool down and we'll meet back here at four. Okay? Tao doesn't answer. 102.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 94 94 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I said В‘okay?' You won't do anything without me. You meet me back here at four? Say В‘okay.'

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Okay. Tao storms out the back door. Walt pours more coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 95 Walt soaks in the tub. It's filled with bubbles. Walt looks over at Daisy who rests on a towel in the corner. Walt lights a CIGARETTE and exhales. Daisy curls up her lips at the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Give me a break, it's the first time I've ever smoked in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 96 Walt meticulously mows his lawn. He carefully trims around the fence and birdbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 97 Martin finishes cutting Walt's hair.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: There, all done. Ten bucks American.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you still have steady enough hands to give a guy a straight shave, you withered, old Italian mummy?

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: You? A straight shave? You've never ordered a straight shave, ever.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's right. I always wondered what they were like. Unless you're too goddamned busy? 103.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 94 94 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: No, no. That's fine. Let me heat up a towel. Walt hands Martin the Barber a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Here's a twenty. Keep the change in case you slip and hit my jugular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 98 Walt gets fitted for a new suit. The OLD TAILOR carefully measures Walt's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: So you can take it in right here?

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Take about an hour.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's great. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Never had a fitted suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 99 Walt comes in and Father Janovich looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Mr. Kowalski, what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I've come for confession.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Oh Lord Jesus, what have you done?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nothing. Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What are you up to? 104.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 97 97 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Are you going to let me confess or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 100 Walt calmly sits on one side and a very nervous, sweating Father Janovich sits on the other.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: How long has it been since your last confession?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Forever. Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: What are your sins, my son.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: In 1968, I kissed Betty Jablonski at the work Christmas party. Dorothy was talking with the other wives and it just happened.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Yes. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I made nine hundred dollars profit selling a boat and motor and never reported the taxes which is the same as stealing.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Yes. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And lastly, I was never close to my two sons. I don't know them. I didn't know how.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Whatta you mean, В‘That's it?' It's bothered me for years. 105.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 99 99 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: God loves and forgives you. Say ten В‘Hail Marys' and five В‘Our Fathers.' Are you going to retaliate for what happened to Sue? Walt says nothing. Father Janovich looks hard at Walt.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'm going over to that house today, Mr. Kowalski.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: It is. And every other day until you see the folly in what you are planning.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I gotta go, Padre. Busy day ahead.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Go in peace.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I am at peace. Walt and Father Janovich shake hands. Walt exits. Father Janovich exhales loudly and drops into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Je -- zuz -- Christ. INT. WALT'S KITCHEN - 3:51 P.M. 101 101 Walt carefully reassembles the two weapons he just cleaned and oiled. Tao comes in and looks down at the two weapons -- The 30-06 M1 GARAND RIFLE and the COLT .45 PISTOL. Tao picks up the heavy RIFLE.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Which one do I get?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You ever fire a weapon? 106.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 100 100 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No. Tao aims the rifle at an imaginary target.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Put that down. I got something for you.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: In Korea, October, 1952. We were sent up to sweep a Chink machine gun nest that had carved us up pretty bad. I was the only one who came back... I received the Silver Star. I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: When we went up that hill, we knew it was ten to one against us, but we went anyway. This trouble now, it's similar. We're walking right into it. We might not be coming home tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: The hell we won't. We're going to roll in there and tear ass.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool, these guys are waiting for that exact reaction. Tao is quiet for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How many what?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: How many men did you kill in Korea?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Thirteen for sure. Probably more. 107.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 101 101 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What was it like to kill a man?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Go get the Silver Star. It's in a blue wooden box in the cellar. Tao goes downstairs. He turns on the light and goes into the cellar. Tao locates a BLUE WOODEN BOX and opens it. Tao holds up the MEDAL. He looks at it closely. AND WHAM -- Walt slams the heavy cellar DOOR shut behind him. Walt slides the BOLT LOCK into place with a loud CLICK. Tao couldn't kick his way out of there in ten years. Of course he tries anyway. Tao is furious. He throws things.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?! Let me out of here, you goddamned son- of-a-bitch!!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Quit smashing everything. You'll never get out of there, so just relax.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: You let me out, you crazy old fuck, or I will kill you when I get out of here. Tao pounds on the door. Walt pounds back with a strength and authority which startles Tao.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You want to know how it feels to kill a man? It feels goddamned lousy. And it feels even worse when you get a medal for bravery right after you mowed down some scared kid when he tries to give up. A dumb, scared, little gook, just about your age. I shot him with the same rifle you just held upstairs. 108.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 101 101 (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 110
dialogues.text: I've thought about that kid for fifty years. And I promise you, boy, you want no part of it. Me, I've got blood on my hands. I'm soiled. Forgive me for tricking you like a dope. I'll call someone and have them let you out later.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: No! Let me out!! Tao pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You've come a long way. I'm proud to call you a friend. You have your whole life ahead of you, whereas this is what I do. I finish things. You'd just get in the way. Sorry. Walt goes back upstairs, leaving Tao locked up in his cellar. Tao howls to be let out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 102 Walt walks out his front door with Daisy on her leash. He walks over to Tao's house. Phong sits in a lawnchair and glares at Walt. She yells in Hmong as Walt walks straight up to her.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Aw, pipe down, you hag.

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an evil man. I've seen your kind before. Back home, white soldiers came to our villages and filled our young men's minds with ideas of glory. Then you'd lead them away to their deaths. Walt, of course, has no idea what she said.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Fine, I hate you too. 109.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 111
dialogues.text: Walt holds out the DOG LEASH to Phong. She looks down at Daisy and back at Walt. She lashes out again in Hmong.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I need you to watch my dog. Walt holds the leash closer. Phong folds her arms in defiance. Walt exhales loudly. Walt lifts up one of the LEGS OF HER LAWNCHAIR and slips the loop of the leash underneath it so Daisy can't follow him.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Her name is Daisy. Walt bends down on one knee and lovingly pets Daisy. He scratches her belly.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You take it easy, old gal. You good old girl. Walt gets up and walks away without looking back. Phong is stunned; she is silent for once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 103 Walt walks in and sits down. He nods to the regulars.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: DARREL
dialogues.text: Walter, how are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Never been better.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Beer and a shot, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I think I'll have something different. Walt looks at the liquor display. At the pinnacle of bottles sits a bottle of Johnnie Walker Blue.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Think I'll try that Johnnie Walker Blue Label. 110.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 102 102 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 112
dialogues.text: The regulars all В“OoooooВ” and В“AhhhhhhhВ” at Walt's or

dialogues.speaker: MEL
dialogues.text: Whatta ya win the lottery, Wally?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Naw, just having something special. Walt sips his Scotch and nods. It's good.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Why don't you get all the guys the same.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I'm sure. This is too good not to be shared. Walt finishes his Scotch and points for one more. Several regulars hold up their drinks towards Walt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 104 Walt slips into the phone booth. He puts in change and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 105 Sue weakly answers the phone next to her bed.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's Walt. The key to my front door is under the ceramic turtle. Open the door and go let your brother out of the cellar. I have to go. The line goes dead as Walt hangs up. Sue jumps up out of bed, pulls on some clothes and runs downstairs. Phong blocks her path. Phong grabs Sue by the arms. 111.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 103 103 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHONG
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that? Where are you going? You tell me what's going on?! Sue squirms away from Phong and runs outside. On her way over to Walt's house, she sees Daisy leashed to Phong's chair. It scares Sue even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 106 Father Janovich paces back and forth. The SQUAD CAR pulls up to him, which is exactly what he's been afraid of all day.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Father, we have to go.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. If we're not here, there will be bloodshed.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: We've been here for hours. We can't afford to anchor a unit to one location.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'm begging you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: I just got word from my Sergeant, we're pulling the plug.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: I'm staying.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: No you aren't. My orders are specific. You came with us, you're leaving with us. Father Janovich looks hard at the duplex before getting into the SQUAD CAR. The SQUAD CAR drives off. Walt pulls up in front, gets out of his pickup and slams the door. He looks at the duplex. It's a total eyesore.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a goddamned mess. You slopes should be ashamed of yourselves. 112.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 105 105 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAGE 114
dialogues.text: Walt walks up the sidewalk and stops twenty feet from the duplex. Six very scared, very jittery Hmong gangbangers look out at Walt from various doorways and windows.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that all you swamp rats or is there more vermin scurrying in the shadows? Smokie and Spider step out and stand on the porch. Smokie smiles at Walt. Walt spits on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure that you'd...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Shut up, gook. I'm not here to listen to one goddamned syllable of what a shrimp-dicked little baby midget like you has to say. Spider pulls his PISTOL.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: That's right, boy. Defend your boyfriend after he or you or whoever rapes a member of your family. Your own blood, for Christ's sake. Go ahead, pull your pistols, just like a bunch of ridiculous miniature toy cowboys. Smokie and several other Hmong gangbangers pull their guns.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have no honor. You're the scum of the earth and when you're gone, do you think anyone will care? No one will mourn. You won't be missed. All the Hmong are spooked at Walt's absolute lack of fear.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKIE
dialogues.text: Where's Tao, old man? He too scared to come and stick up for himself? 113.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 106 106 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. Tao is too good for this. You pukes aren't worth one second of his time. Walt slowly puts a CIGARETTE in his mouth. Even this slight movement has the gangbangers waving their PISTOLS around. Walt laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You boys are a little bit jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: You watch it, old man.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, I think you'd better watch it. Walt looks around. Other than the gangbangers, a small group of people have gathered to watch this showdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 107 Sue opens the front door, runs to the stairwell and pounds down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Tao? Tao, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: I'M DOWN HERE
dialogues.text: She unlocks the CELLAR DOOR. Tao comes out in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: He left without me!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Where? Where'd he go?!

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: He went to Smokie's without me. Tao takes the stairs two steps at a time. 114.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 106 106 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No! No, Tao! Sue grabs Tao's legs and hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No! Don't you dare! Stay away from them, Tao! I don't want anyone else getting hurt.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: NO, TAO. NO
dialogues.text: They struggle at the top of the stairs and spill into the kitchen floor. Tao runs for the door when something catches his eye... The kitchen table. The RIFLE and PISTOL are still there. Walt purposely left the guns at home.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: Oh God! NO!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 108 WALT AND COMPANY...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Anybody got a light? No? I got one. Walt's slight grin fades. He mutters to himself...

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hail Mary, full of grace. Walt reaches into his coat pocket. Six Hmong gangbangers simultaneously level their PISTOLS and FIRE. BULLETS FLY. Walt is struck down. People scream. Walt falls dead. A ZIPPO lighter clutched in his hand. Walt never intended to kill anyone. Self-sacrifice. 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 109 Tao and Sue arrive just as Smokie, Spider and company are being driven away in Police cars. Tao looks at Smokie in the squad car. Smokie no longer looks tough or hard, he just looks scared. On the street, Walt is being bagged by the ambulance crew. Father Janovich prays over him. Tao steps up to a POLICE OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: You have to step back.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: He was a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: I said step back. Tao turns to the HMONG POLICE OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: What happened, man? The Hmong Police Officer looks at the WHITE POLICE OFFICER and then to Tao.

dialogues.speaker: HMONG POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: You heard him, step back. Tao speaks to the HMONG OFFICER in their native language.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, man, it's important. He's my friend. Tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: HMONG POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old guy reaches for a lighter and they gunned him down. The gang said the old guy was here to kill them, but he didn't have a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: TAO
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going to happen? 116. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HMONG POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We actually have witnesses for once. These guys are going away big time. The WHITE OFFICER yells at the HMONG OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Officer Chang, get those people back.

dialogues.speaker: HMONG POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You have to step back now. Tao hugs his sister. Sue openly weeps. Tao holds it in. He looks at his friend Walt as the bag is zipped over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 110 Tao and Sue wait in front. Tao wears a suit, Sue is in a traditional Hmong dress. A TAXI pulls up and they get in. Sitting on the porch is Phong who rocks back and forth in her rocking chair. Phong holds Daisy in her arms, gently petting the old dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 111 We're at the funeral of Walter Kowalski. Walt is dressed in his new suit. Along with the crowd you'd expect, Tao and Sue are seated near the front. Walt's sons and family are there. Mitch gives Tao a dirty look. Tao looks back at him, his gaze bores right through Mitch. Mitch looks away. Father Janovich steps up to the pulpit and speaks. 117.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 109 109 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER JANOVICH
dialogues.text: Walt Kowalski once said to me I didn't know anything about life or death because В‘I was an overeducated, 27-year-old virgin who held the hands of superstitious old women and promised them eternity.' Walt definitely had no problem В‘calling it like he saw it.' But Walt was right. I knew really nothing about life or death until I got to know Walt. And boy, did I learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 112 All of Walt's family are seated in an office as a LAWYER reads Walt Kowalski's will. Tao is present along with Walt's family.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Which brings us to our last item. And again, please forgive the language used in Mr. Kowalski's will. I'm simply reading it as it was written. The LAWYER takes a sip of water before reading...

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: В‘And to my friend, Tao Vang Lor, I leave my 1972 Gran Torino on the condition that you don't choptop the roof like a damned spick, don't paint any idiotic flames on it like some white-trash hillbilly and don't put a big gay spoiler on the rear-end like you see on all the other zipper heads' cars. It just looks like hell. If you can refrain from doing any of that, it's yours. FADE OUT.
